title: Default math operators
description: All generic math operations like addition, multiplication, division subtraction and power are implemented in natural syntax and respect order of operations.

title: Selecting and advanced operations
description:
Every operator and group of operators of any equation can be selected at any point.
 To select, LEFT-CLICK (main mouse button) in the OUTPUT (the rendered formula), to highlight and trigger further actions (the buttons will become available to execute operations on the selection).
 Every kind of operator has a distinct set of possible actions.
Try experimenting with the actions. Here the "Show Export Structure" was used.
This one is particularly interesting in finding out how the system stores and represents the input.

title: Advanced navigation
description:
For easier selection you do not always need to click operators in the gui.
 You can use the helper buttons "Sel. Parent","Sel. First Child","Sel. Next Sibling","Sel. Previous Sibling"
They all do what they say.
The buttons are also mapped to the 4 arrow keys. (Caution, arrow keys only work, just right after an operator has been clicked. They stop working as soon as the focus is shifted somewhere else.)

title: Implied multiplication
description:
Multiplication will be implied between most operations. Operator precedence is taken into account when implying.
Some other operations may also be implied, for example here a - in a sum implies the + operation (however this can be overwritten by explicitly setting the *).

title: Advanced mathematical functions
description:
Functions with a more complex syntax, (that for example require more than one argument in front or behind) can be written with the "function(...arguments;)" syntax.
 The ";"-sign can be used at any time to delimit arguments structurally (and may be necessary in function arguments).

storage.bc264306-c6e3-40bb-8b5e-f2016a2cba7c: {"textValue":"sum(s1; s2; s3) ; int(i1; i2; i3; i4) ; exp(a) ; func(f; x) ; funcrm(f; x) ; sin(x) ; cos(x)"}

title: Single argument functions
description: If a function takes only one argument, automatic bracket-wrapping is implied.

storage.5395084d-43d4-4c3b-b47d-a8f0ec004093: {"textValue":"exp(x y z) = exp(x * y * z) = exp((x*y*z))"}

title: Structural operators
description:
There exist a set of structural symbols. Their use may result in the creation of a "structural_container".
These are always used to store elements that do not fit into a common operator-tree.
Structural containers can be created at will, using the ";"-sign.
The "{}"-sign allows to provide an empty argument if required arguments need to be left empty.

storage.2e4eb9d7-9237-446f-9917-5ba2d9f5eb3f: {"textValue":"x/y <=> x/y = x/y != sum({} {} {}) ; x/y < x/y > x/y <= x/y >= x/y"}

title: Constants
description:
Several constants are pre-provided.
Calling "Fold Numbers" on them will result in them presenting their values.

storage.efc3f7c6-9008-42be-bb4a-65518ebd79ee: {"textValue":"pi ; inf ; e ; i ; sqrt2 ; psi ; phi"}

title: Variables - definition and usage
description:
When Variables are typed, they can be accessed at the bottom of the page (in this case the bottom of the example) in the "Variables"-Section (for space-reasons only displayed in relevant examples).
In the example the operations "Define Variable", "Unpack", "Define Variable", "Fold Numbers" have been used.
(Fold Numbers and number based operations remain working, no matter how deep nested variables are.)
Recursive or self-referencing variables break everything currently, so do not do it, I guess.

title: User-defined Macros utility
description:
Alongside the dynamic variables, there exists the possibility to define custom macros.
They can be managed at the bottom of the page (in this case the bottom of the example) in the "Macros"-Section (for space-reasons only displayed in relevant examples).
These basically work like the pre-defined functions.
 They may have arguments or not. The argument number is controlled by the largest number next to a "#" in the "macro-output".
 The same argument ("#<ARGUMENTNUMBER>") can be used multiple times in the output, in that case only the first instance is clickable.
The smallest argument-number is #0 (so if your macro contains a #1, it requires at least two arguments/parameters).

title: Pure Macros and Macro recursion
description:
If a macro is not assumed to be raw Latex AND can be error-less parsed to an operator, the macro will be INSTANTLY REPLACED with the parsed content. 
 Thereby the macros may still take arguments. Macros even support using other macros.
HOWEVER if a macro includes itself, you will produce infinite recursion and crash your instance (!! This is not checked for, you have been warned.)

title: Bra-Ket with orthonormal evaluation
description:
There are helpers for writing in the physical Bra-c-ket notation.
"MergeAndEvaluateBraKet" may be used to check for orthonormal overlap.
For selection the "Sel. Parent" button may be helpful.

storage.111aaf5f-eb11-4eb6-8737-fcc57342b09c: {"textValue":"bra(up up up) ket(up down up) ; bracket((up ;down; up);H;(up ;down; up))"}

title: Fermionic- and Bosonic- Creation- and Annihilation-Operators
description:
As an example for non-commutative operators, these operators are implemented.
Evaluating such "Commutation-Relations" was the initial reason this tool was developed.
In this example, the "Commute with Subsequent" operation was applied. The string argument may hold the "degree of freedom", so basically the label of the operator. This also has effect on the commutation, as different degrees of freedom always (anti-)commute.

title: Operator string ordering (works for non-commutative operators)
description:
This demonstrated the "Order Operator Strings" Functionality.
A full ordering can be performed even if operators are non-commutative (deals with - and possible additional terms).
This also gives an example use for macros, as it is most likely intended to abbreviate the used qm-operator constructors.

title: Order all operator strings in a sum
description:
There is this convenient shorthand "All Summands Order Operator String" if you want to execute "Order Operator Strings" on every product in a sum at once
This also automatically eliminates some of the canceling terms (if there are any) to reduce output length.
Also works if the operator string is inside a negation.

title: Group equal operators in sum
description:
Simple. If the same term happens to appear multiple times in sum, the "Group Equal Elements" helper collects them.
This function works better, if "All Summands Order Operator String" was called before on the sum, because then the program is more likely to pick up on the equal terms.

title: Sort the summands in a sum
description:
Not only is it possible to order products, but also sums with the "Order Summands" action.
The program tries to order helpfully, but this is not always easy.
For better visibility e.g. negations of operators will be sorted always right to the right of the operator.

title: Factor out the most common left factor
description:
If you have a long sum of many summands, there is a good chance some things can be factored if the summands are products.
Here the program can attempt to factor out the leftmost operator if multiple products share a common first factor.
Just call "Factor out left" on a sum.
Again works best if "All Summands Order Operator String" was called beforehand.

title: Distribute and cancel from sums
description:
The handy "Distribute" function can be used to expand products of sums.
After the terms have been fully expanded, the "EliminateCancelingTerms" function of sums is kicked into action.
In this case "Order Operator Strings" needed to be executed twice manually (the author of the tool mainly uses it for non-commutative operators, so ordering per default is not such a clean idea).

title: Complex numbers
description:
Complex numbers can be accessed through the complex unit "i", as well as the "complex" helper.
In this example the "MultiplyComplexNumbers" function was used to calculate the total product.

title: LaTeX
description:
As the tool uses LaTeX under the hood, generally all normal LaTeX commands should be additionally working.
There may be conflicts with the operator parsing in some cases, but I hope I didn't break anything important.
If something is majorly broken, feel free to open an issue.
Because the "(" and ")" symbols perform a custom role in the parser, you can not use these when writing custom latex. But this environment provides the custom "\lbracket" and "\rbracket" macros.
 You used to need to sprinkle some ";" and "{}" to "force the parser into submission", but this SHOULD be fixed by now.

title: Custom LaTeX macros
description:
If you want to use any of the math symbols that are processed by the parser when writing raw LaTeX, you may use the provided replacement macros.
Caution. If you export the LaTeX code into an external project of yours after using these, you need to define the macros in your Preamble or it won't work there.

title: Commutators
description:
Support for commutator and anti-commutator helpers.
They each have an action to write them as a difference ("Write Out (Anti) Commutator").

title: Helpers for exponentials
description:
There are some builtin helpers for re-writing natural exponents.
On the left side, "Use Eulers Formula" was used.
On the right side, "Write As Series".

title: Helpers: swap/rename
description:
For many of the more complicated helpers, the action only becomes available if specific pre-requirements are met. Often you need to select multiple "additional arguments" in the correct order.
If you want to swap two variables (rename a to b and b to a), you need to select an operator first (LEFT-CLICK/main click button -> blue selection).
The operator itself AND all its children will be considered for swap-rename (as you see, only operators inside the blue-selected operator experiences any effect).
"Additional arguments" can be selected with RIGHT-CLICK (secondary mouse button/context menu button -> red selection).
If you select EXACTLY two additional operators as arguments, you can trigger "Rename With Swap"
After selecting an additional operator (red) you can de-select it, by clicking again.
There are operations for which the order of selections matters (see below).

title: Helpers: pack same into variables
description:
This helper allows you to pack all operators that EQUAL the CONTENT of a variable into said variable.
Select the operator whose scope you want to modify as main selection.
Then select exactly ONE VARIABLE of which you want to process the content of.
Then select "Pack Same Variables" to make all instances of the variable content to turn into the variable in the selected scope.
(Here you see, that the content of VAR is exp(l) in the variables drawer)
For an explanation on how to provide multiple arguments, see "Helpers: swap/rename"

title: Helpers: replace x all with y
description:
This helper allows you to mass replace all instances of one operator with another operator.
Select the operator whose scope you want to modify as main selection.
Then select FIRST the operator you want to replace (it will also replace all equivalent operators in the scope).
Secondly select the operator with that you want to replace the first selection.
Finally select "Replace All With", which in this case replaces two of the delta functions with 0 (And as they are zero, they are automatically simplified-out).
For an explanation on how to provide multiple arguments, see "Helpers: swap/rename"

title: Helpers: cancel elements
description:
Sometimes you need to cancel elements where you know that they are inverse, but the program doesn't
With this helper you can achieve exactly this.
Select the operator whose scope you want to modify as main selection.
Then select the two operators you want the program to cancel as additional arguments.
For an explanation on how to provide multiple arguments, see "Helpers: swap/rename"
One the left side of this example, the operation "Adjacent Elements Cancel" was executed. One the right side of this example, the operation "Elements Cancel".
These operations are provided for sums and products as the main selection.

title: Delta functions: split into product
description:
QM operators with multiple indices may generate delta functions with multiple indices in a structural container if commuted.
Just use the simple "Split Into Product" helper to generate a product of deltas from these.

title: Delta functions: split all
description:
As often many delta function need to be split with "Split Into Product", there is a helper for global splitting
This helper requires some different steps to be activated.
First select ANY delta function as main selection, to tell the program to consider delta-actions.
Then select as many operators as additional arguments as you like.
EVERY delta function that meets the criteria and is inside the scope of AT LEAST ONE additional selection will be split, when "Split All Deltas Into Products" is selected.

title: Delta functions: sum over arguments
description:
To evaluate delta functions, you can use the replace-with-helper, but to make this more convenient a shorthand was added.
First select the specific delta function you want to evaluate as main selection.
Then select as many operators as additional arguments as you like. In ALL selected operator scopes, all matching operators will be replaced.
This function does NOT depend on the sum in any capacity. You need to think yourself over what parts of the equation and what arguments you want to sum.
Here we have called "Sum Over Second Argument", as the sum has m as a running index. Therefore all m have been replaced with l inside the red-selected scope.
If we had called "Sum Over First Argument", all l would have been replaced by m, even though that would not make sense in this context, so be careful over what you sum.

storage.4de5b2d7-837b-4b94-8791-cdc9898c66b2: {"textValue":"sum(m inf ((func(f m) l exp(l) m delta(l m))+ m l))"}

title: Delta functions: sum all equivalent over arguments
description:
Again, as one often needs to evaluate the same delta function many times in e.g. a long sum, there s a global execution helper.
Again his helper requires careful consideration before you apply it.
First select the specific delta function you want to evaluate as main selection.
Then select as many operators as additional arguments as you like. In ALL selected operator scopes the program will SEARCH for delta functions that match the delta function you selected as main argument.
The program will then call the "Sum Over First/Second Argument" modification with the DIRECT PARENT of the selected delta function as input scope.
TAKE THIS INTO CONSIDERATION. The program will not think for you what parts are logical to sum over!
(Notice there remains one m because it did not share a direct parent with one of the deltas and a delta remained, because it has different arguments than the main selection)

storage.34ccd55f-3714-4c71-9b95-728e91e2ba20: {"textValue":"delta(m l) func(f m)+m+delta(m l) func(g m)+delta(m l+1) func(h m)"}
